Elected Upon Resignation of J. Trueman
Thompson -- Book May Be Called
"Johns Hopkins Hullabaloo," with
Name of Class Eliminated.

At a meeting of the 1917 Hullabaloo board last Wednesday, J.
Trueman Thompson resigned his
position as editor-in-chief, and
Henry L. Straus was elected to
take his place.
Mr. Thompson gave as the reason for his resignation, which was
anticipated in last week's issue,
the fact that the store which he
has recently established in the
Civil Engineering Building, for
the furnishing of technical supplies to the students, would require
all the time which he would have
free from his studie. Mr. Thompson was elected editor of the
Hullabaloo early last year, and
during the past season had already taken a number of preparatory steps towards the shaping of
the publication.
,
Henry L. Straus, the new editor-in-chief, was formerly on the
board in the position of art editcir.
Mr. Straus is in the engineering
department.
Immediately after his election,
the editor announced to a representative of THE NEWS-LETTER
that the board was seriously considering the advisability of
changing the name of the book
from the 1917 Hullabaloo to the
Johns Hopkins Hullabaloo, and
of making it in fact, as well as in
title, the book of the University,
rather than the book of the Senior
class.
If this plan is adopted, Mr.
Straus added, the book would of
course still contain the pictures
of the seniors, but more space
would be devoted to undergraduate activities in general. One feature of the publication will be
the quantify of pictures it will
contain. It is the intention of the
board to surpass in this department any Hullabaloo ever published. In order to secure these
pictures, the board asks all students to take as many pictures as
possible of the athletic games,
the Homewood buildings and
campus, and all other scenes of
University interest. •
Neither John T. Binford nor A.
Ashley Weech returned to Hopkins this fall, and, as a consequence, their positions were formally declared to be vacant. The
resignation of Frederick P. Hall
from the board was accepted at
the same time. His resignation
leaves four vacant positions on
the Hullabaloo staff. These vacancies, in all probability, will be
filled before the end of the week.

PROF. WOOD AGAIN CO-AUTHOR

RIFLE CLUB WINS SECOND MATCH

USED BY HOPKINS MEN

Class Teams to Be Formed in Near
Future--If Enough Interest is Shown,
There is Chance of 'Varsity
Recognition for Sport.

With Arthur Train,Publishes ''The Moon
Maker," an Imaginative Story of
How the World is Saved by a
Disentegrating Ray.

The Oliver Typewriter

Basket-ball practice is to start
almost immediately. As soon as
a- number of candidates will report for work in the old gymnasium, next to McCoy Hall,
games will begin.
After teams have been organized, an interclass schedule will
be arranged. The three upper
classes will have practically no
difficulty in bringing out their
last year's stars, and from the
number of freshmen who are
anxious to play, a very formidable five should be found.
It is possible that a college
team will be selected this year to
meet quintets from several.of the
nearby colleges and schools. It
, is rumored that if this team
makes-a good showing, basket-ball
may become a recognized college
activity.
As usual, Mr. Theodore Kistler will have charge of this sport.
In order to help find candidates among the freshmen for
basket-ball and the other teams,
Mr. Kistler and Dr. Abrecrpmbie
are keeping records of what each
freshman did in athletics at
"Prep" school.

Prof. Robert Williams Wood,
of the Physics Department, has
again collaborated with Arthur
Train in the production of an imaginative story, "'the Moon Maker," which embodies some of the
latest scientific ideas:
Mr. Train and Professor Wood
were the authors of "The Man
Who Rocked the Earth" — published in the Saturday Evening
Post—a story of the invention of
"The Ring," a flying or anti-gravity machine that was held aloft
and propelled by powerful rays.
The story told how the inventor,
who used this machine with its
rays of almost inconceivable
power to stop the European war,
was himself killed soon after in
an accident to the machinery. It
then went on to describe how Professor Hooker, of Harvard, discovered the machine.
In the new serial, now running
in the Cosmopolitan, Professor
Hooker masters the mechanism of
"The Ring" and flies with it to
Washington, D. C. When astronomers announce that a small asteroid is due to collide with the
earth, Professor Hooker volunteers to deflect its course or to
destroy it entirely by means of
"The Ring."
Dr. Wood, as professor of experimental physics, is especially
equipped for supplying the scientific ideas incorporated in the
story:

soon as possible.

BALTIMORE, MD., OCT. 16, 1916.
A Matter of Respect.

With the beginning of this college year, Hopkins enters upon a
new era. Upon us, the first generation of that era, there rests a
great responsibility—it is we who
must establish at Homewood the
traditions by which alone can
ideals of the old Hopkins be perpetuated. We are the first; the
spirit which we implant will grow
and strengthen; the missteps that
we make will rut deeper and
deeper.
The Hopkins seal is the highest insignia of our University. To
see that seal trodden upon, made
to serve as a door mat for every
Mot, disregarded and defiled, is
a spectacle which no Hopkins
man should tolerate, far less a
spectacle in which he should
share. Yet, during the past two
weeks, the seal in the floor of the
Academic Building entrance hall
has been treated with no more
veneration than if it had been one
of the tiles about it. It has been
thoughtlessness—but thoughtlessness_ which must be immediately
and forever eradicated.
There is no college worthy of
the term in the country in which
such an action is not looked upon
as the most despicable breach of
loyalty. We should no more think
of setting foot upon the Univer-

- An Experiment in Applied Physics.
Occasionally, in a moment of relaxation, the scientist lays aside
his test tubes and blow pipes,stretches his arms a bit, and then
casually gives the world a glimpse
of just what could happen to it
if he were concerned with discovering details, instead of principles. So is born a vaccine, a new
food, an electric light. Then the
scientist goes back to his real
work, and the world again begins
to regard objective truth as an
ideal somewhat vague, and undoubtedly impractical.
"The Moon Maker" is a title
more suggestive of Jules Verne or
of G. II. Wells than of a Hopkins
professor of physics—which, of
course, makes the fact that Professor Robert W. Wood is the coauthor of the book doubly significant. We expect fiction from a
writer of fiction; it is distinctly
more unusual to find it emanating
from a member of the Royal Society of Sciences. True enough,
it is physical fiction, but it is because of the very manner in which
the facts and discoveries of physics are applied to an extremely
interesting eventuality, that the
story commands attention.
It is a serious and almost universal misconception that the students of the world are blinded to
the romance of their study: The
truth lies far the other way. The
romance which is open to their
eyes is so infinitely more fascinating than that which sifts
through to the eyes of the layman,
that they very seldom take the
trouble to lower their vision to
the ordinary sphere. When they
(lo, and when the result takes the
form of a story such as '"The
Moon Maker,"- the universal misconception is a trifle staggered.

"SHOULD STUDENTS STUDY ?" asked them not to select men
President of Reed College Compiles
Interesting Statistics as to Relation
of College Work with Success
in After Life.

Dr, William T. Foster, president of Reed \ College, has published an article in a recent number of Harper's Magazine on the
undergraduate work of Americfin
Colleges, which has called forth
comment throughout the country.
The article written under the title
"Should Students Study?" is an
arraignment of the doctrines
which enjoins that studies should
not interfere with a college education.
"Is high scholarship worth the
effort?" asks President Foster.
"In other words, have colleges devised courses of study which bear
any relation to the probable careers of their students? Is there
any evidence that a man who attains high marks is more likely
to achieve success after graduation than a man who is content
with passing marks?"
He then brings these facts,
among others, to the answering of
his queries:
"In the Harvard Law School, of
those who graduated from college
with no special honor, only 61/2
per cent. attained distinction. Of
those who graduated with honor
from the college, 22 per cent, attained distinction in the Law
School; of those who graduated
with great honor, 40 per cent; and
of those who graduated with highest honor, 60 per cent.
"If rank in college has nothing
to do with success in life, we
should expect to find that 15 per
cent of the graduates in 'Who's
Who' were Phi Beta Kappa men.
But they surpass this expectancy
by nearly 100 per cent.
"As one measure of success in
life, we may take the judgment
of certain men. In so far as we
accept their judgment, our findings concerning the relation between college studies and this
kind of success will seem important to us. Here, as in most questions of educational aim, we can
do no better for the present than
take the consensus of opinion of
competent judges.
"Using this measure for success, I endeavored to find out
whether the members of the Class
of 1894 of Harvard College who
had become notable in their lifework had been notable in their
studies. I therefore asked three
judges to select, independently,
the most successful men from that
class. I chose as judges the dean
of the college, the secretary of the
Alumni Association, and a professor in Columbia University,
who is a member of the class, became I thought that these men
came nearer than any others to
knowing all members of the class..
I left each judge free to use his
own definition of success, but I

whose achievements appeared to
be (Inc principally to family
wealth or position. The judges
agreed in naming twenty-three
successful men. I then had the
entire umlergraduate records of
these men accurately copied from
the college records and compared
with the standings of twentythree men chosen at random
from the same class.
"The result was striking. The
men who were thus named as
most successful attained in their
college studies nearly four times
as many. highest grades as the
random selection. To the credit
of the successful men are 196
'A's;' to the credit of the other
111(11, only O.
-Following a similar plan, three
judges selected the most successful men among the gradUates of
the first 24 (1878-1901). classes
from the University of Oregon.
An examination of the scholarship
records of these men showed that
53 per cent. had been good students and 17 per -cent. had been
weak students. Of the graduates
who were notregarded as successful, 52 per cent. had been weak
students and only 12 per cent. had
been good students. •
"The undergraduate who is
really eager to excel in any lifework, and who is brave enough to
face the facts, Nv i11 take down that
sign from the walls of his room,
`Do not let your studies interfere
with your college education,' and
replace it with this one: 'Do not
let your College Life interfere
with your life's ambition.' The
boy without ambition will take for
his motto, 'Let well enough
alone,' oblivious to the fqct thin t
people who are content to let well
enough alone rarely do well
enough."

Of these institutions, 101 have the

22 have it in some departments

TRACK TEAM HAS GOOD OUTLOOK

A Column in Which the Correspondents

Large Squad Turns Out for Cross-country
Running—Several Promising Newcomers at University—Only Two
Very Serious Losses.

New Regulations Adopted in the College
for Freshman Class Include Some
Highly Original Rites and Interesting Ceremonies.

All letters intended for publication must
be concise.
No attention will be paid to anonymous
letters, but names signed as an evidence of

The publication of a letter is not to be

Asks for Better Cheering.

October 13, 1916.
To the Editor of THE NEW -LETTER:
Sir—I wish to call attention to
the lack ,of spirit displayed by the
students in the matter of reporting for cheer practice. Last
Thursday the cheer leaders attempted to hold a practice on the
steps of the Civil Engineering
Building. If the football team
had had to look for encouragement from the cheering that was
done on that day, they would have
gotten discouragement instead.
Why cannot everyone realize the
importance of cheering at the
games? Not mere cheering, but
Systematic, mass cheering.
Many a player, when feeling
weak and disheartened, has been
urged to his feet by the yells of
his fellow-students, and sent
across the line by the strength intilled into him by the enthusiasm of the cheers. Also, many a
game has been lost because the
team lacked the support and the
feeling of confidence that only
good cheering can give.
The Hopkins team needs all the
ilpport and assistance that 'can
be given it, if the Black and Blue
is to come out on top. It needs
every pair of lungs in the University shouting for victory. If every
freshman, sophomore,'junior, and
senior does his-part, the team will
do theirs. Hopkins, at Homewood, should have as efficient
cheering as Hopkins did at McCoy
Hall. If everyone conscientiously
helps, we can have much better.
We need it. Let us all he there,
and let us all yell "our heads off."
JUNIOR.

A promising number of candidates answered the tall of Captain
Straus last T_hursday afternoon,
and reported for fall track practice. About 30 men are reporting
daily for cross-country work,
while the field men have also begun work at the pits.
Not for a number of years has
the outlook been so bright for a
successful track season at Hopkins. With the loss of only two
men to overcome — Connolly,
whose reputation makes elaboration unnecessary, and Reese, who
showed marked ability as a freshman last year—and with the backbone of last year's team to build
upon, as represented by Straus,
Hall, Uhler, Weeks, Rosen, Perkins, Firor, Lyman, and others,
the team should be well-balanced
and unusually strong. Further
than this, a number of new men
with creditable performances behind them, have enrolled in the
University this fall, some of whom
are already practicing with the
squad. Among these are Sullivan,
a former captain and quartermiler at Catholic\ University;
Snowden, who has twice represented Princeton in the dashes in
Intercollegiate
the
Northern
Championships; Bernhard, of Rochester College, a middle-distance
man of ability; and Smith, of
Baltimore City College, who
aroused a great deal of interest in
interscholastic circles last spring.
In addition to these men, there is
Leadbetter, a Bowdoin star, enrolled in our medical school, who
captured second place at the Intercollegiates last year in the
hammer-throw, and who also
throws the discus with considerable skill.
This year will also see a full
Hopkins team entered in the
South Atlantic cross-country run,
to be held in Washington under
the auspices of the Catholic University of .that city. During the
winter the usual meets in this section of the country will be attended, foremost among which is
the Johns Hopkins-Fifth Regiment games. A splendid spring
schedule will be offered to Baltimore followers of the sport at
Homewood field.

No Tennis Tournament to Be Held.
Despite the fact that rumors of
a tennis tournament to be held at
the University this fall have been
circulating about the University
for two weeks, both Manager
Hammond and Captain Taylor, of
the tennis team, have stated positively that no plans for any
tournament have yet been made,
She — Is Princeton in New
and probably will not be made. York?
Although several fall tournaments
Student (truthfully reflective)
have been held at Hopkins in pre- —Yes, a grea t part of the time.
vious years, none was held either
last year or the year before last.

Joe—Jewels! Ah, none—I took

Elected Upon Resignation of J. Trueman
Thompson -- Book May Be Called
"Johns Hopkins Hullabaloo," with
Name of Class Eliminated.

At a meeting of the 1917 Hullabaloo board last Wednesday, J.
Trueman Thompson resigned his
position as editor-in-chief, and
Henry L. Straus was elected to
take his place.
Mr. Thompson gave as the reason for his resignation, which was
anticipated in last week's issue,
the fact that the store which he
has recently established in the
Civil Engineering Building, for
the furnishing of technical supplies to the students, would require
all the time which he would have
free from his studie. Mr. Thompson was elected editor of the
Hullabaloo early last year, and
during the past season had already taken a number of preparatory steps towards the shaping of
the publication.
,
Henry L. Straus, the new editor-in-chief, was formerly on the
board in the position of art editcir.
Mr. Straus is in the engineering
department.
Immediately after his election,
the editor announced to a representative of THE NEWS-LETTER
that the board was seriously considering the advisability of
changing the name of the book
from the 1917 Hullabaloo to the
Johns Hopkins Hullabaloo, and
of making it in fact, as well as in
title, the book of the University,
rather than the book of the Senior
class.
If this plan is adopted, Mr.
Straus added, the book would of
course still contain the pictures
of the seniors, but more space
would be devoted to undergraduate activities in general. One feature of the publication will be
the quantify of pictures it will
contain. It is the intention of the
board to surpass in this department any Hullabaloo ever published. In order to secure these
pictures, the board asks all students to take as many pictures as
possible of the athletic games,
the Homewood buildings and
campus, and all other scenes of
University interest. •
Neither John T. Binford nor A.
Ashley Weech returned to Hopkins this fall, and, as a consequence, their positions were formally declared to be vacant. The
resignation of Frederick P. Hall
from the board was accepted at
the same time. His resignation
leaves four vacant positions on
the Hullabaloo staff. These vacancies, in all probability, will be
filled before the end of the week.

Maker," an Imaginative Story of

The Oliver Typewriter

Basket-ball practice is to start
almost immediately. As soon as
a- number of candidates will report for work in the old gymnasium, next to McCoy Hall,
games will begin.
After teams have been organized, an interclass schedule will
be arranged. The three upper
classes will have practically no
difficulty in bringing out their
last year's stars, and from the
number of freshmen who are
anxious to play, a very formidable five should be found.
It is possible that a college
team will be selected this year to
meet quintets from several.of the
nearby colleges and schools. It
, is rumored that if this team
makes-a good showing, basket-ball
may become a recognized college
activity.
As usual, Mr. Theodore Kistler will have charge of this sport.
In order to help find candidates among the freshmen for
basket-ball and the other teams,
Mr. Kistler and Dr. Abrecrpmbie
are keeping records of what each
freshman did in athletics at
"Prep" school.

Prof. Robert Williams Wood,
of the Physics Department, has
again collaborated with Arthur
Train in the production of an imaginative story, "'the Moon Maker," which embodies some of the
latest scientific ideas:
Mr. Train and Professor Wood
were the authors of "The Man
Who Rocked the Earth" — published in the Saturday Evening
Post—a story of the invention of
"The Ring," a flying or anti-gravity machine that was held aloft
and propelled by powerful rays.
The story told how the inventor,
who used this machine with its
rays of almost inconceivable
power to stop the European war,
was himself killed soon after in
an accident to the machinery. It
then went on to describe how Professor Hooker, of Harvard, discovered the machine.
In the new serial, now running
in the Cosmopolitan, Professor
Hooker masters the mechanism of
"The Ring" and flies with it to
Washington, D. C. When astronomers announce that a small asteroid is due to collide with the
earth, Professor Hooker volunteers to deflect its course or to
destroy it entirely by means of
"The Ring."
Dr. Wood, as professor of experimental physics, is especially
equipped for supplying the scientific ideas incorporated in the
story:

ORGANIZATION FOR YEAR

compelled to resign the position
of assistant general secretary of
the Y. M. C. A., and Allan K.
Chalmers,'18, has been aivointed
to fill his place. Chalmer's successor as vice-president has not
Yet been appointed.
P. B. Strobel, '17, and John C.
Rouse, '18, have been , appointed
chairmen of the Deputation Work
and Community Service committees, respectively, and all students
interested in this work should
communicate with these men as
soon as possible.
Chapel services began last week
With Mr. Morriss, of Central
Y• M. C. A., as leader. Services
are held every morning in the
Donovan Room at 8.40 o'clock.
Doctor Wykoff, of Madison Avenue M. E. Church, will be the
leader for this week.

President Frank J. Goodnow
Willi address the Bar Association
of Baltimore city on "The Budget
System" at a meeting to be held
this Tuesday evening in the courtroom of the Superior Court.

BALTIMORE, MD., OCT. 16, 1916.
A Matter of Respect.

With the beginning of this college year, Hopkins enters upon a
new era. Upon us, the first generation of that era, there rests a
great responsibility—it is we who
must establish at Homewood the
traditions by which alone can
ideals of the old Hopkins be perpetuated. We are the first; the
spirit which we implant will grow
and strengthen; the missteps that
we make will rut deeper and
deeper.
The Hopkins seal is the highest insignia of our University. To
see that seal trodden upon, made
to serve as a door mat for every
Mot, disregarded and defiled, is
a spectacle which no Hopkins
man should tolerate, far less a
spectacle in which he should
share. Yet, during the past two
weeks, the seal in the floor of the
Academic Building entrance hall
has been treated with no more
veneration than if it had been one
of the tiles about it. It has been
thoughtlessness—but thoughtlessness_ which must be immediately
and forever eradicated.
There is no college worthy of
the term in the country in which
such an action is not looked upon
as the most despicable breach of
loyalty. We should no more think
of setting foot upon the Univer-

- An Experiment in Applied Physics.
Occasionally, in a moment of relaxation, the scientist lays aside
his test tubes and blow pipes,stretches his arms a bit, and then
casually gives the world a glimpse
of just what could happen to it
if he were concerned with discovering details, instead of principles. So is born a vaccine, a new
food, an electric light. Then the
scientist goes back to his real
work, and the world again begins
to regard objective truth as an
ideal somewhat vague, and undoubtedly impractical.
"The Moon Maker" is a title
more suggestive of Jules Verne or
of G. II. Wells than of a Hopkins
professor of physics—which, of
course, makes the fact that Professor Robert W. Wood is the coauthor of the book doubly significant. We expect fiction from a
writer of fiction; it is distinctly
more unusual to find it emanating
from a member of the Royal Society of Sciences. True enough,
it is physical fiction, but it is because of the very manner in which
the facts and discoveries of physics are applied to an extremely
interesting eventuality, that the
story commands attention.
It is a serious and almost universal misconception that the students of the world are blinded to
the romance of their study: The
truth lies far the other way. The
romance which is open to their
eyes is so infinitely more fascinating than that which sifts
through to the eyes of the layman,
that they very seldom take the
trouble to lower their vision to
the ordinary sphere. When they
(lo, and when the result takes the
form of a story such as '"The
Moon Maker,"- the universal misconception is a trifle staggered.

"SHOULD STUDENTS STUDY ?" asked them not to select men
President of Reed College Compiles
Interesting Statistics as to Relation
of College Work with Success
in After Life.

Dr, William T. Foster, president of Reed \ College, has published an article in a recent number of Harper's Magazine on the
undergraduate work of Americfin
Colleges, which has called forth
comment throughout the country.
The article written under the title
"Should Students Study?" is an
arraignment of the doctrines
which enjoins that studies should
not interfere with a college education.
"Is high scholarship worth the
effort?" asks President Foster.
"In other words, have colleges devised courses of study which bear
any relation to the probable careers of their students? Is there
any evidence that a man who attains high marks is more likely
to achieve success after graduation than a man who is content
with passing marks?"
He then brings these facts,
among others, to the answering of
his queries:
"In the Harvard Law School, of
those who graduated from college
with no special honor, only 61/2
per cent. attained distinction. Of
those who graduated with honor
from the college, 22 per cent, attained distinction in the Law
School; of those who graduated
with great honor, 40 per cent; and
of those who graduated with highest honor, 60 per cent.
"If rank in college has nothing
to do with success in life, we
should expect to find that 15 per
cent of the graduates in 'Who's
Who' were Phi Beta Kappa men.
But they surpass this expectancy
by nearly 100 per cent.
"As one measure of success in
life, we may take the judgment
of certain men. In so far as we
accept their judgment, our findings concerning the relation between college studies and this
kind of success will seem important to us. Here, as in most questions of educational aim, we can
do no better for the present than
take the consensus of opinion of
competent judges.
"Using this measure for success, I endeavored to find out
whether the members of the Class
of 1894 of Harvard College who
had become notable in their lifework had been notable in their
studies. I therefore asked three
judges to select, independently,
the most successful men from that
class. I chose as judges the dean
of the college, the secretary of the
Alumni Association, and a professor in Columbia University,
who is a member of the class, became I thought that these men
came nearer than any others to
knowing all members of the class..
I left each judge free to use his
own definition of success, but I

whose achievements appeared to
be (Inc principally to family
wealth or position. The judges
agreed in naming twenty-three
successful men. I then had the
entire umlergraduate records of
these men accurately copied from
the college records and compared
with the standings of twentythree men chosen at random
from the same class.
"The result was striking. The
men who were thus named as
most successful attained in their
college studies nearly four times
as many. highest grades as the
random selection. To the credit
of the successful men are 196
'A's;' to the credit of the other
111(11, only O.
-Following a similar plan, three
judges selected the most successful men among the gradUates of
the first 24 (1878-1901). classes
from the University of Oregon.
An examination of the scholarship
records of these men showed that
53 per cent. had been good students and 17 per -cent. had been
weak students. Of the graduates
who were notregarded as successful, 52 per cent. had been weak
students and only 12 per cent. had
been good students. •
"The undergraduate who is
really eager to excel in any lifework, and who is brave enough to
face the facts, Nv i11 take down that
sign from the walls of his room,
`Do not let your studies interfere
with your college education,' and
replace it with this one: 'Do not
let your College Life interfere
with your life's ambition.' The
boy without ambition will take for
his motto, 'Let well enough
alone,' oblivious to the fqct thin t
people who are content to let well
enough alone rarely do well
enough."

Asks for Better Cheering.

October 13, 1916.
To the Editor of THE NEW -LETTER:
Sir—I wish to call attention to
the lack ,of spirit displayed by the
students in the matter of reporting for cheer practice. Last
Thursday the cheer leaders attempted to hold a practice on the
steps of the Civil Engineering
Building. If the football team
had had to look for encouragement from the cheering that was
done on that day, they would have
gotten discouragement instead.
Why cannot everyone realize the
importance of cheering at the
games? Not mere cheering, but
Systematic, mass cheering.
Many a player, when feeling
weak and disheartened, has been
urged to his feet by the yells of
his fellow-students, and sent
across the line by the strength intilled into him by the enthusiasm of the cheers. Also, many a
game has been lost because the
team lacked the support and the
feeling of confidence that only
good cheering can give.
The Hopkins team needs all the
ilpport and assistance that 'can
be given it, if the Black and Blue
is to come out on top. It needs
every pair of lungs in the University shouting for victory. If every
freshman, sophomore,'junior, and
senior does his-part, the team will
do theirs. Hopkins, at Homewood, should have as efficient
cheering as Hopkins did at McCoy
Hall. If everyone conscientiously
helps, we can have much better.
We need it. Let us all he there,
and let us all yell "our heads off."
JUNIOR.

A promising number of candidates answered the tall of Captain
Straus last T_hursday afternoon,
and reported for fall track practice. About 30 men are reporting
daily for cross-country work,
while the field men have also begun work at the pits.
Not for a number of years has
the outlook been so bright for a
successful track season at Hopkins. With the loss of only two
men to overcome — Connolly,
whose reputation makes elaboration unnecessary, and Reese, who
showed marked ability as a freshman last year—and with the backbone of last year's team to build
upon, as represented by Straus,
Hall, Uhler, Weeks, Rosen, Perkins, Firor, Lyman, and others,
the team should be well-balanced
and unusually strong. Further
than this, a number of new men
with creditable performances behind them, have enrolled in the
University this fall, some of whom
are already practicing with the
squad. Among these are Sullivan,
a former captain and quartermiler at Catholic\ University;
Snowden, who has twice represented Princeton in the dashes in
Intercollegiate
the
Northern
Championships; Bernhard, of Rochester College, a middle-distance
man of ability; and Smith, of
Baltimore City College, who
aroused a great deal of interest in
interscholastic circles last spring.
In addition to these men, there is
Leadbetter, a Bowdoin star, enrolled in our medical school, who
captured second place at the Intercollegiates last year in the
hammer-throw, and who also
throws the discus with considerable skill.
This year will also see a full
Hopkins team entered in the
South Atlantic cross-country run,
to be held in Washington under
the auspices of the Catholic University of .that city. During the
winter the usual meets in this section of the country will be attended, foremost among which is
the Johns Hopkins-Fifth Regiment games. A splendid spring
schedule will be offered to Baltimore followers of the sport at
Homewood field.

a tennis tournament to be held at
the University this fall have been
circulating about the University
for two weeks, both Manager
Hammond and Captain Taylor, of
the tennis team, have stated positively that no plans for any
tournament have yet been made,

His quiet leadership has such an

coaches held concerning them. In
Cox, Duncan and Flowers the
team has a trio who are not far

The material has now been sifted in- such a way that the coaches
are able to tell the men on whom
they may count. An analysis of
the squad shows that we have
not enough linemen of sufficient
physical endowment to stand the
pounding incident to the games
now approaching on our schedule.
The coaches are hoping that more
heavy men, weighing 170 pounds
or more, will appear during the
Coming week, and if any suchput

in appearance they can be assured
of a hearty welcome. The line,
as it stands today, is a good one;
but it must be remembered that
relief must be sent in during a
hard-fought game and if there is
any great disparity between the
first and second string men the
'consequence is, in most cases, a
defeat. More heavy linemen is,
therefore, the cry of the coaching
staff.
For the first two games emphasis has been laid on the rushing game in an endeavor to develop a "punch" in the team, and
this method will Ie continued Until .a good straight attack has
been produced. When this has
been done, the polish will then be
applied, but it must be remembered that Hopkins' teams are
proverbially slow, because of the
tardiness of the student body in
becoming adjusted to their new
environment. Nevertlieless, sufficient fighting spirit. is beginning
